results.title: Doctor Who: remembrance of the Daleks
results.creator_credit: Andrew Morgan, John Nathan-Turner and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: The Doctor and Ace (Sophie Aldred) land in London, 1963, amidst an environment of mysterious magnetic fluctuation and a military stake out. Leaping in the back of scientific advisor Professor Rachel Jenson’s wagon, the time lord and his companion find themselves in the thick of a siege in which men are being killed by a mysterious “death ray”. The Doctor informs Group Captain Gilmore, the man in charge, that these are the energy weapons of the Daleks. The Daleks have come to retrieve something the first Doctor left behind at the school of his grand daughter Susan, the powerful Hand of Omega. The Daleks are species divided however, with two warring factions competing for the Hand. On one side there is Dalek Emperor Davros, on the other the renegade Imperial Dalek faction headed by the Supreme Dalek. The Doctor must stop the Daleks from gaining the Hand and protect Group Captain Gilmore and his men from extinction. Boasting more special Dalek induced effects than in previous episodes, Sylvester McCoy starred as the seventh Doctor in this 25th season of the cult series for a period of three years (1987-1989). Written by Ben Aaronovitch.

results.title: Divorce can happen to the nicest people
results.creator_credit: Stephen Smallwood, Consolidated Productions and Paternoster Nominees
results.brief_description: Peter Mayle, author of successful children’s information books such as “Where did I come from?”, examines the issue of divorce in an attempt to reassure children about the anxieties they may be facing in their own lives. The program is geared towards making children understand that divorce is not the end of their family; focusing on why couples fall in and out of love; what happens to parents when they separate and how the family must cope with new responsibilities. The program seeks to comfort children who may be blaming themselves for the family breakup. Animated and simply narrated, this program is more suited to middle primary school children and above.

results.title: Highlands of New Guinea
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
Social and economic changes in the Western Highlands of Papua New Guinea as demonstrated in the construction of an airstrip at Lake Kopiagu and the first Mount Hagen Show. Credits include Stanley Hawes, Frank Bagnall, Maslyn William, Shan Benson, Dennis Hill and Robert Gibbs.

results.title: Water: our problem
results.creator_credit: Joe Scully, John Martin-Jones, Lee Robinson, Maslyn Williams and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
Illustrates our dependence on water and our inability to exist without it. Tells why Australia has water shortages and what is being done to irrigate the great inland tracts from mountainous regions of heavy snowfall and abundant rains. Australia has the largest artesian basin in the world, from which thousands of square miles have been made productive. Scientific progress has been made in the fields of rainmaking by chemical cloud dusting, and desalination of sea water.

results.title: Sir John Monash
results.creator_credit: Jennie Blackwood, John Martin-Jones, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, State Electricity Commission of Victoria and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
Reviews the life and work of the Australian scholar, lawyer, soldier and engineer, Sir John Monash. Shows his career as an engineer; a commander of troops in World War I; and his work as a Commissioner of the State Electricity Commission during the development of Yallourn. Edited by Jennie Blackwood; photographed by Adrian Bodington; sound by Alan Allen; introduction by John West.

results.title: Portrait of an Australian
results.creator_credit: Rhonda Small, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
The development of the myth of the “Typical Australian” of the old days. Myth, legend and romance embody our wishes, attitudes and beliefs. By using old illustrations, songs and ballads, this film traces the character which most Australians foster. The legend emerges from the convict past, the bitter struggles and hardships, the tradition of pioneer and explorer, the stormy gold rush days, the growth of towns and the gradually accepted fact that here were a new distinctive people who later joined together as one nation. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Made in Australia
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall, Chips Rafferty and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
Protectionist economic policies during the Menzies era led to the development of a manufacturing industry in Australia. This document explores Australia’s steel industry, showing its relationship to other heavy industries and its development since the second world war.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Frank Bagnall, Chips Rafferty and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Kondom Agaundo
results.creator_credit: Maslyn Williams and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
Outlines the background and life of Kondom Agaundo, a native leader elected to the Legislative Council as a representative of the people of the Highlands of Papua and New Guinea. Shows his family and tribal life; his leadership, nomination, election and first speech in the House where he tells of his desire to learn.
